metadata.description: Indian laws and landmark cases relevant to animal advocacy
metadata.disclaimer: For reference only. Consult a qualified advocate for legal advice.

constitutional_provisions.title: Right to Life and Personal Liberty
constitutional_provisions.text: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
constitutional_provisions.animal_welfare_relevance: Expanded to animal life in AWBI v. Nagaraja (2014). Also basis for right to clean environment affecting communities near factory farms.
key_cases: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India (1987) 1 SCC 395

constitutional_provisions.title: Organisation of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry
constitutional_provisions.part: Part IV (Directive Principles of State Policy)
constitutional_provisions.text: The State shall endeavour to organise agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines and shall, in particular, take steps for preserving and improving the breeds, and prohibiting the slaughter, of cows and calves and other milch and draught cattle.
constitutional_provisions.animal_welfare_relevance: DPSP — not directly enforceable but guides state policy. Used in conjunction with 51A(g). CAUTION: weaponized by cow vigilante groups.
key_cases: State of Gujarat v. Mirzapur Moti Kureshi (2005) 8 SCC 534

constitutional_provisions.title: Protection and Improvement of Environment
constitutional_provisions.part: Part IV (Directive Principles of State Policy)
constitutional_provisions.text: The State shall endeavour to protect and improve the environment and to safeguard the forests and wild life of the country.
constitutional_provisions.animal_welfare_relevance: Basis for challenging environmental damage from factory farms. Pair with Article 21 for enforceable right to clean environment.
key_cases: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India (1987) 1 SCC 395

constitutional_provisions.title: Fundamental Duty — Compassion for Living Creatures
constitutional_provisions.text: It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to protect and improve the natural environment including forests, lakes, rivers and wild life, and to have compassion for living creatures.
constitutional_provisions.animal_welfare_relevance: THE constitutional anchor. Nagaraja court used this to derive animal rights from the Constitution. Cite in every PIL.
key_cases: People for Animals v. State of Goa (1997)

statutes.name: Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 1960

key_sections.Section 3: Duty of persons having charge of animals to take reasonable measures to ensure their well-being
key_sections.Section 4: Establishment of Animal Welfare Board of India (AWBI)
key_sections.Section 11: Treating animals cruelly — defines 12 forms of cruelty
key_sections.Section 11(1)(a): Beating, kicking, over-riding, over-driving, over-loading, torturing
key_sections.Section 11(1)(d): Conveying or carrying in a vehicle causing unnecessary suffering
key_sections.Section 11(1)(e): Keeping in cage not reasonably large and comfortable
key_sections.Section 11(1)(h): Neglecting to provide sufficient food, drink or shelter
key_sections.Section 38: Power of Central Government to make rules

statutes.penalties: First offence: Rs 10-50. Subsequent: Rs 25-100 OR imprisonment up to 3 months OR both. Woefully inadequate.
statutes.amendment_status: Multiple amendment bills pending to increase penalties. PCA Amendment Bill proposed Rs 50,000-75,000 for first offence.

statutes.name: Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (Transport of Livestock) Rules, 1978

key_rules.Rule 4: Certificate of fitness from veterinary doctor required before transport
key_rules.Rule 5: Animals must be provided adequate food and water
key_rules.Rule 6: Diseased, blind, emaciated, pregnant (advanced) animals cannot be transported
key_rules.Rule 7: Vehicle specifications — adequate ventilation, non-slip flooring
key_rules.Rule 8: Maximum number of animals per vehicle
key_rules.Rule 9: Animals not to be transported more than 36 hours without rest and feed
key_rules.Rule 47: Poultry specific — max 4 birds per coop of 60x45x30 cm

statutes.name: Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (Transport of Animals on Foot) Rules, 2001

key_rules.Rule 3: Animals must be fit for transport, certified by veterinarian
key_rules.Rule 6: Rest at intervals not exceeding 5 hours
key_rules.Rule 9: Animals not to be tied with nose ropes causing pain

statutes.name: Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (Slaughter House) Rules, 2001

key_rules.Rule 6: Animals must be stunned before slaughter (humane killing)
key_rules.Rule 6(2): No animal to be slaughtered in sight of another
key_rules.Rule 7: Sick, pregnant, animals under 3 months cannot be slaughtered
key_rules.Rule 8: No slaughter between sunset and sunrise

statutes.name: Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006

key_sections.Section 31: Licensing and registration of food business operators
key_sections.Section 38: Power of Food Safety Officers to inspect
key_sections.Section 59: Punishment for unsafe food — 6 months to life imprisonment
key_sections.Section 63: Operating without license — Rs 5 lakhs fine

key_regulations: FSS (Food Products Standards and Food Additives) Regulations, 2011

statutes.name: Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974
statutes.key_provisions: Consent to Establish and Consent to Operate from SPCB required. Section 33A: SPCB can issue directions for closure. Violations: imprisonment up to 6 years and fine.

statutes.name: Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981
statutes.key_provisions: Consent required for industrial operations. Section 31A: SPCB directions for closure. Applicable to poultry farms (ammonia, particulates) and rendering plants.

statutes.name: Environment (Protection) Act, 1986
statutes.key_provisions: Umbrella legislation. Section 5: Power to issue directions. Section 15: Penalty up to 5 years imprisonment and Rs 1 lakh fine. EIA Notification 2006 for environmental clearance.

statutes.name: Right to Information Act, 2005
statutes.key_provisions: Section 6: Application for information. Section 7: Response within 30 days. Section 19: Appeals — first and second. Section 20: Penalty on PIO Rs 250/day up to Rs 25,000.

statutes.name: Indian Penal Code — Sections 428 and 429
statutes.key_provisions: Section 428: Mischief by killing or maiming animal of value Rs 10+ — imprisonment up to 2 years. Section 429: Mischief by killing animal of value Rs 50+ — imprisonment up to 5 years. STRONGER than PCA Act penalties.

landmark_cases.name: Animal Welfare Board of India v. A. Nagaraja & Ors.
landmark_cases.subject: Jallikattu and bullock-cart races
landmark_cases.holding: Banned jallikattu and bullock-cart races. Animals have constitutional rights — right to live with dignity, right to life, right not to be tortured. Five freedoms read into PCA Act.
landmark_cases.significance: Most important animal rights judgment in Indian legal history. Constitutional basis for all animal welfare litigation.

landmark_cases.name: People for Animals v. State of Goa
landmark_cases.subject: Bull fights (dhirio) in Goa
landmark_cases.holding: Banned bull fights. Cultural/traditional practices do not override PCA Act.

landmark_cases.name: N.R. Nair & Ors v. Union of India & Ors
landmark_cases.subject: Use of animals in circuses
landmark_cases.holding: Upheld restrictions on animals in circuses. State has positive obligation to prevent cruelty.
landmark_cases.significance: State's affirmative duty to protect animals.

landmark_cases.name: Gauri Maulekhi v. Union of India
landmark_cases.subject: Illegal cattle transport to Nepal (Gadhimai festival)
landmark_cases.holding: Directed strict enforcement of Transport Rules. States must prevent illegal cattle transport.
landmark_cases.significance: Key precedent for transport rule enforcement.

landmark_cases.name: Laxmi Narain Modi v. Union of India
landmark_cases.subject: Unlicensed slaughterhouses
landmark_cases.holding: Directed all state governments to close unlicensed slaughterhouses and ensure compliance with Slaughter House Rules 2001.
landmark_cases.significance: Direct authority for demanding slaughterhouse compliance.

landmark_cases.name: State of Gujarat v. Mirzapur Moti Kureshi Kassab Jamat
landmark_cases.subject: Total ban on cow/bull/bullock slaughter in Gujarat
landmark_cases.holding: Upheld total ban. Article 48 + 48A + 51A(g) provide sufficient basis.
landmark_cases.significance: CAUTION: Used by cow vigilante groups. Cite carefully. Good for DPSP analysis, dangerous in communal context.

landmark_cases.name: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India
landmark_cases.subject: Oleum gas leak — absolute liability
landmark_cases.holding: Established absolute liability doctrine and right to clean environment under Article 21.
landmark_cases.significance: Foundation for environmental PIL against factory farms.

landmark_cases.name: Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum v. Union of India
landmark_cases.subject: Tannery pollution in Vellore
landmark_cases.holding: Established Precautionary Principle and Polluter Pays Principle as part of Indian environmental law.
landmark_cases.significance: Key for CAFO pollution cases — polluter must pay for cleanup.

landmark_cases.name: Indian Council for Enviro-Legal Action v. Union of India
landmark_cases.subject: Chemical industry pollution in Rajasthan
landmark_cases.holding: Polluters liable for remediation. Government must enforce environmental laws.

landmark_cases.name: Akhil Bharat Goseva Sangh v. State of Andhra Pradesh
landmark_cases.subject: Cattle slaughter regulations
landmark_cases.holding: States have power to regulate slaughter. Must balance with livelihood rights.
landmark_cases.significance: Nuanced — recognizes both welfare and livelihood dimensions.
